text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Israeli newspapers on Wednesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
JERUSALEM POST
- Attorney-General Michael Ben-Yair resigns, denies being forced out.
- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Egyptian Foreign Minister Amr Moussa express hope for improved relations.
- Israeli parliament debates...doughnut deliveries?
- Property firms eye Hapoalim's Amot stake.
- Adviser to Palestinian President Yasser Arafat: Rethink Israel-Palestinian Authority economic pact.
- Finance Minister Dan Meridor: Low internal revenue predictions for '97 are "relative".
- Lehman Brothers: Leumi to lead Israeli banks in '97 earnings.
- Menorah Insurance manager Shabtai Angel dies at 60.
GLOBES
- Efforts to reach a compromise on budget cut.
- Rise of 0.5 percent in average salary in third quarter to 5,042 shekels.
HAARETZ
- Netanyahu seeks attorney-general more in line with Likud positions.
- Proposal under consideration in prime minister's office to effectively implement Hebron deal without signing it.
- Settler lectures Golani soldiers on "importance of settlement in Hebron".
- Deputy Mayor of Jerusalem Shmuel Meir killed in car crach in north of city.
MAARIV
- Electricity prices going up 4.5 percent.
- 2,500 will be made redundant at Bezeq within five years.
YEDIOTH AHRONOTH
- Eliyakim Rubinstein, the former cabinet secretary and negotiator with Jordan, is among the candidates to take the place of attorney-general.
